title: Section 230 Repeal Collateral Damage
context: Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act shields platforms from liability for user-generated content. Critics from both political sides want it repealed or reformed — the left says it enables hate speech and misinformation, the right says it enables censorship. But Section 230 doesn't just protect Big Tech. It protects every website with a comment section, every forum, every review site, every small social platform. Repealing it wouldn't hurt Facebook — they can afford lawyers. It would kill the open internet.
hypothesis: Repealing Section 230 will hold platforms accountable for harmful content and improve the internet.

chain.root: Repeal or significantly weaken Section 230 protections

effects.label: Small platforms and websites can't afford liability risk
effects.impact: Comment sections, forums, and review sites shut down

children.label: Any website hosting user content becomes a lawsuit target
Small businesses remove review sections, forums close, blogs disable comments
Only companies with large legal teams can afford to host user content

effects.label: Big Tech consolidates — they can afford compliance

children.label: Facebook, Google, and Amazon have legal departments larger than most companies
New social platforms become impossible to launch — liability too high
The regulation meant to constrain Big Tech becomes their moat

effects.label: Platforms over-moderate to avoid liability
effects.impact: Anything potentially controversial gets removed preemptively

children.label: Political speech, satire, and criticism suppressed as liability risk
Whistleblower content removed — platforms can't risk hosting it
The internet becomes a sanitized corporate space

effects.label: Paradoxically, moderation incentives reverse
effects.impact: Platforms may moderate LESS to claim they're not publishers

children.label: If moderating makes you liable, the rational choice is to not moderate at all
Platforms argue they're neutral conduits — any curation creates liability

impact.after: Thousands (only those who can afford legal risk)

dontIf: You believe repealing 230 will primarily affect Big Tech — it won't
You haven't modeled the impact on small websites, forums, and review platforms
ifYouMust: Reform narrowly — target specific harms (CSAM, terrorism) rather than broad repeal
Include safe harbors for good-faith moderation efforts
Exempt small platforms below a user threshold from new liability
Require transparency reports rather than imposing content liability

alternatives.name: Transparency requirements
alternatives.note: Require platforms to disclose moderation policies and enforcement data — accountability without liability

alternatives.name: Duty of care framework
alternatives.note: Require reasonable efforts to address known harms without making platforms liable for all user content

alternatives.name: Algorithmic accountability
alternatives.note: Hold platforms responsible for what they amplify, not what users post

falsifiability: Repealing Section 230 reduces harmful content online without reducing legitimate speech or small platform viability
Small websites and forums can afford the legal costs of content liability without Section 230 protection
Big Tech market share decreases after Section 230 repeal as new competitors emerge

seo.description: Section 230 repeal wouldn't hurt Big Tech — they can afford lawyers. It would kill forums, review sites, and small platforms. The open internet depends on intermediary liability protection.
